SafetyInspectionBy: State - Florida Division of Emergency Management

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
C&S Wholesale Grocers' senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding community.  The Corporate Compliance Team assists the facility in administering safety and environmental policies. The Corporate Compliance Team is made up of the following personnel:



?    Senior Director of Corporate Refrigeration

?    Senior Manager of Corporate of Refrigeration

?    Director of Environmental & OSHA Compliance

?    PSM-RMP Regulatory Manager

?    Corporate Manager of Facilities Compliance

?    OSHA Regulatory Manager

?    Environmental Compliance Manager



The Maintenance Manager periodically evaluates the health and safety practices of facility employees to ensure compliance, and oversees implementation of the safety and environmental programs.  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE 



The primary business of C&S - Baldwin is to provide refrigerated warehousing and storage for various food products.  In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 37,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.



The Baldwin facility is located at 15500 Beaver Street West in Jacksonville, Florida.  The facility consists of areas for dry, frozen, and cooler storage of non-perishable and perishable items for distribution.



Off-site Release Scenarios



C&S has conducted an OCA based on the EPA document titled "RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines," and used the EPA's RMP*Comp Version 1.07 to estimate the distance traveled to a toxic endpoint defined by the EPA regulation. This data were then used to estimate the potential impact caused by a release

from each of the regulated substances.



Worst-Case Release Scenarios



As required by regulations, scenarios were considered where the entire capacity of the largest vessel for each regulated chemical at the facility was released in 10 minutes. Although these scenarios are highly unlikely in the event of a release, it provides the local responding agencies with a maximum possible impact in the event of an accidental release. In considering these releases, the most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used. Passive mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.



Alternative Release Scenarios



Alternative scenarios were developed to assess what potential impact may occur in the event of a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarios for each of the regulated chemicals. Several possible release scenarios were considered, and the scenarios with the greatest offsite impact were chosen. In considering the alternative release scenario, the default meteorological conditions for alternative scenarios were used in RMP*Comp. These scenarios represent a more realistic release, and have a downwind distance and impact considerably smaller than the worst-case scenario. No passive or active mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.



Process Description



The Thermosyphon Tank receives liquid ammonia from the condensers; it provides liquid ammonia to the High Pressure Receiver. The Thermosyphon Tank also provides liquid ammonia to all Compressor Oil Coolers. The High Pressure Receiver provides liquid ammonia to the +5?F Intercooler and the Glycol Chiller. The +5?F Intercooler provides liquid ammonia to the produce, dairy, meat, banana rooms, floral, seafood, milk, and dock area via liquid pumps. The +5?F Intercooler also feeds subcooled liquid to the -35?F Low Temp Recirculator. The -35?F Low Temperature Recirculator provides liquid ammonia to the 0?F and -20?F f

reezers via liquid pumps.



The evaporators maintain the appropriate room temperatures by transferring heat from the air in the room to the ammonia inside the coils, using fans to move air across the coils. The -35?F Low Temperature Recirculator pumps liquid ammonia to the 0?F and -20?F Freezer evaporators. The -35?F Low Temperature Recirculator also collects the liquid/vapor mixture from these evaporators; the vapor returned is then drawn to the booster compressors. 



The +5?F Intercooler pumps liquid ammonia to the produce, dairy, meat, banana rooms, floral, seafood, milk, and dock area evaporators. The +5?F Intercooler also collects the liquid/vapor mixture from these evaporators; the vapor returned is then drawn to the high stage compressors.

There are two Freezer Air Curtains that provide an air curtain of downward flow air to hold the colder temperature within the freezer when the freezer doorway is opened, to prevent the warmer temperature from entering the freezer and causing unsafe icing conditions due to condensation freezing, and to prevent freeze-up of the doorway area while loading and unloading operations are in progress. Hot Gas is supplied to the air curtain. Boil-off condensate created by the hot gas and the 0? colder temperature from the freezer is returned to the high temperature recirculated suction line and back to +5?F Intercooler.



The Glycol Chiller is used to transfer heat from the glycol to the ammonia for the Banana Rooms. The Glycol Chiller utilizes high pressure liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver.  This high pressure liquid is expanded in the shell and tube section of the Glycol Chiller where it absorbs heat from the glycol that passes through the tubes.  As the ammonia absorbs heat it boils and collects in the Glycol Chiller surge drum mounted on top of the shell and tube section.  Glycol is chilled to a preset temperature by controlling the pressure in the surge drum through a pressure regulating valve where ammonia f

lows back to the +5?F Intercooler. 



Ammonia vapor from the -35?F Low Temperature Recirculator is routed through a suction header to provide suction for the booster compressors (BC-1 through BC-3). During the compression phase in the compressor, the temperature of the ammonia vapor rises and the pressure of the ammonia vapor increases. The low pressure booster discharge flows from the compressors via a vapor head to the +5?F Intercooler.



The high stage compressors (HSC-1 thru HSC-5) draw the suction return vapor that is collected in the +5?F Intercooler and compresses it to discharge high pressure vapor (hot gas). The compressors are the primary energy input into the system. Hot gas is used internally within the system to assist with defrosting the evaporator coils based on a timed cycle. The main high stage discharge flow is routed to the Condensers, which discharge the latent heat in the ammonia to the atmosphere using sprayed water and fans, resulting in high pressure liquid ammonia. This liquid is recycled into the Thermosyphon Tank. 



There is an automatic purger located in the Engine Room. The Auto Purger provides a means to automatically remove foul gas from the system. In Automatic mode, the purger will sequence through the purge points condensing ammonia vapor in the purger chamber and purging any foul gas from the system. In Manual mode, an individual purge point can be selected.



Ammonia sensors are located in the Engine Room and within each refrigerated space throughout the warehouse. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:



1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and

2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).



These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on-site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance p

rograms that have been implemented by C&S - Baldwin to prevent the accidental release of ammonia from the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia system is operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre-Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that C&S - Baldwin's employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.



It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors in the Engine Room which will alert operators in the event of a low-level ammonia detection and cease operation of the refrigeration system in the event of a high-level detection.  There are also ammonia detectors located throughout the freezer warehouse that will alert operators in the event of an ammonia detection in those locations.  An off-site alarm company monitors the ammonia

detection system while the facility is unmanned.  In the event of a release while the facility is unmanned, the off-site alarm company will notify the Maintenance Manager and Refrigeration Technicians.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no reportable releases of ammonia at the facility over the past five years (June 2014 - June 2019). There have been no releases of ammonia resulting in injuries at the facility either.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Response Plan (plan) in effect at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  



- save lives;

- minimize and avoid injuries;

- protect the environment; and

- minimize property damage.



The program complies with 29 CFR 1910.38.  The site also has some internal emergency response capability and is developing a program to comply with paragraph (q) of 29 CFR 1910.120.  The current plan has been coordinated with the local Fire Department. The City of Jacksonville's Hazardous Materials Response Team would coordinate and/or assist if an incident were to occur.  Notification is made locally by dialing 911, and by notifying Florida State Warning Point at 1-(800) 832-8224.



There is a specific Corporate C&S program (CEHS-0042) which outlines the training, qualifications and procedures for authorized ammonia Incident responders and observers.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures and the Emergency Response Team holds regular drills.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



In 2000, the refrigeration system was thoroughly examined for safety hazards by way of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  In addition, three Revalidations of the Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted as follows:

Previous studies have been conducted at the facility as follows [40 CFR 68.67(a)].



?    PHA Study -2000 

?    PHA Rev

alidation 1 - 2005

?    PHA Revalidation 2 - 2010

?    PHA Revalidation 3 - 2015



The studies consisted of:



- What-If Studies

- series of safety checklists; and

- facility inspection.



The mitigation measures (recommendations) include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.
